results.title: Mad Max
results.creator_credit: George Miller, Byron Kennedy, Kennedy Miller Productions and Mad Max Films
results.brief_description: Mad Max marked the debut of Australian director George Miller and his first collaboration with Mel Gibson. Part science fiction, part road movie, “Mad Max” is a futuristic vision of a post-apocalyptic Australia where ordered society is fast disintegrating into violent chaos. In this anarchic setting, rogue gangs menacingly roam the land in search of petrol (a vital and increasingly scarce resource), spoils of looting and bloodthirsty fun. Mel Gibson stars as Max Rockatansky, a good cop made mad by the death of his wife and child and the hands of a gang of feral bikies. The film follows Max as he embarks on a personal vendetta to avenge the death of his family, armed with anger, a gun and his car - “the last of the V-8 interceptors”. “Mad Max” has a much-imitated visual and thematic style - gang members are clad in filthy rags with maimed bodies; the landscape is bleak and featureless; camps are transitory pit-stops between war zones; and machines rule their owners. “Mad Max”, with its ordinary hero and car culture narrative, fits neatly into the zeitgeist of 1970s filmmaking. A nihilistic road movie, fuelled by male angst, “Mad Max” is a thrilling, truly original film that remains a highlight of Australian film history.

results.title: Love Letters from Teralba Road
results.creator_credit: Stephen Wallace, Richard Brennan and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: This excellent film was one of the first significant films of the revived Australian film industry to focus on working-class characters. It has a raw, painful and moving story, based on real love letters uncovered in a flat in Newcastle by director Stephen Wallace, and the first impressive screen performance from a young Bryan Brown. Cast also includes Kris McQuade, Gia Carides, Joy Hruby, Kevin Leslie, Ashe Venn. Photography by Tom Cowan, assistant photography by Martha Ansara.

results.title: Lipstick on your collar
results.creator_credit: Renny Rye, Rosemarie Whitman and Whistling Gypsy Production for Channel 4
results.brief_description: By acclaimed writer Dennis Potter, “Lipstick on your collar” is a romantic comedy which transports the viewer back to the 1950’s and the era of rock and roll. Mick Hopper, working in the War Office as part of his National Service, uses his imagination to escape the drudgery and bully boy officers. By transporting them into his fantasies as rock and roll singers he deals with the harshness of life. When Private Francis, a young Welshman joins Mick, they join forces. Often astonishing and never dull, “Lipstick on your collar” is a must for all Dennis Potter fans.

results.title: Like it is
results.creator_credit: Paul Oremland, Tracey Gardiner and Channel Four Films
results.brief_description: This low-budget romantic drama marks Paul Oremland’s directorial debut. Craig is a 21 year old boxer from Blackpool, making cash from illegal bare-knuckle fights. A chance meeting outside a club leads him to a brief sexual encounter with Matt, a self-assured disc-jockey from London. He flees the escalating violence of Blackpool and turns up on Matt’s doorstep where he is introduced to the freedom of Soho, an openly gay world he never imagined existed. As the pair become more involved the illusions on which their relationship is built begins to crumble, not helped by Matt’s scheming gay boss (Roger Daltrey) and possessive flatmate, who seek to break them up. Cast includes Steve Bell, Ian Rose and Dani Behr.

results.title: Leo Beuerman
results.brief_description: Documents the life of Leo Beuerman, an unusual man, physically handicapped since birth, describing his ability to overcome diversity and his philosophy of life. Tells how Leo was able to see a path through his handicap and arrive at a point where he is able to enjoy life. Background music sets a moody and relaxed feel to this unusual and interesting film. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Leaving Las Vegas (D)
results.creator_credit: Mike Figgis, Anne Stewart, Lila Cazès and Initial Productions (US)
results.brief_description: This unlikely love story between a prostitute and an alcoholic won Nicholas Cage an Oscar for Best Actor as well as accolades from various other film festivals. Alcoholic screenwriter Ben, (Nicholas Cage) having lost his wife, child and now his job heads to Las Vegas on a mission to drink himself to death. He picks up prostitute Sera (Elizabeth Shue), they share a night together, numerous drinks and form a semblance of a relationship. She is aware of his mission, his lack of commitment and his love for alcohol which may surpass that of his feelings for her, but desperately clings to him for companionship. They form a relationship on the agreement that she will not ask him to stop drinking. The film is clouded by the halo of Ben’s alcoholism and Sera’s unhappy situation, but is lifted by the strange tenderness they share. Also starring Julian Sands and Richard Lewis.

results.title: La Commune (Paris 1871)
results.creator_credit: Peter Watkins, Paul Saadoun, 13 Productions, Arte, La Sept and Le Musee D'Orsay
results.brief_description: Filmmaker and media critic Peter Watkins directs this epic documentary on the Paris Commune of 1871, an event following the Franco-Prussian War in which France was defeated. Whilst the reign of Napoleon III collapsed, a disgruntled group of commoners decided to take charge, creating their own commune within Paris, thus forming a separatist government that adhered to a type of Marxist ethos. In Watkins’ treatment of the event, he effectively critiques modern media as well as commenting upon the illusive and subjective nature of history. Over 200 mostly non-professional actors re-enact the era, slipping in and out of character, discussing their views on the events they are representing. Two rival 19th century TV stations report on the insurrection; one is directed from within the commune and the other is a CNN type of organisation presenting a sensationalist view. Frightened Parisians are interviewed and argue constantly about the validity of the issues, including the rights of women, education issues, the role of the Church and freedom of the press, as the battle for Paris rages. Watkins’ film is a fascinating view of a little known historical period as well as an evocative and thought-provoking meditation upon our media saturated lives and the power of television. Watkins challenges the constraints of documentary filmmaking dictated by networks and liberates his six-hour story from such limitations. In French with English subtitles.
